abstractText: This Nepalese paper manuscript contains the Saptavāra, the Mañjuśrīnāmasaṅgīti and the Daśabalastavastotra. The Saptavāra ‘Seven Days’ usually incorporates the Vasudhārā (substituted in this manuscript by the Vasundhārānāmāṣṭottaraśataka), Vajravidāraṇā, Gaṇapatihṛdayā, Uṣṇīṣavijayā, Parṇaśavarī/Prajñāpāramitā, Mārīcī, and Grahamātṛkā. This collection associates each dhāraṇī with a specific day of the week, a tradition going back to at least the sixteenth century in Nepal. The Mañjuśrīnāmasaṅgīti is a popular Buddhist tantric work, which consists primarily of 162 verses associated with Mañjuśrī, the Bodhisattva of wisdom. The Daśabalastavastotra is a Buddhist hymn to the ten powers of an illuminated being. According to the colophon placed at the end of the Mañjuśrīnāmasaṅgīti, the manuscript was written in Kathmandu (Kāṣṭhamaṇḍapa), probably in the Tarumūla Mahāvihāra (written taramūdra), in 1663 CE, under the reign of Jayapratāpa Malla (1641-1674), and it was commissioned by a monk named Ratnasiṃha .
